title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: Open-source AI program can answer science questions better than humans
items.description: Developed by and for academics, OpenScholar aims to improve searches of the ballooning scientific literature

items.title: Loss of ‘hunger hormone’ has made snakes masters of fasting
items.description: Ditching ghrelin genes may have helped a wide variety of reptiles deal with a boom-or-bust feeding schedule

items.title: Senate panel slams Trump’s NIH chief for grant cuts, vaccine views
items.description: Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle decry disruptions to biomedical research under Jay Bhattacharya

items.title: Brain cells birth zombielike transport vesicles
items.description: Shed from the surfaces of astrocytes, “zombosomes” flit between cells, carrying proteins linked to disease

items.title: As the world warms, freezing rain shifts to the U.S. South
items.description: Recent winter storm traced the path of an emerging ice corridor

items.title: Serious side effects dim hopes for the first chikungunya vaccine
items.description: The shots fell short during a massive outbreak on a French island. A new vaccine may be safer

items.title: Lawmakers spend big on home state science projects
items.description: Kentucky Senator Mitch McConnell, king of congressional earmarks, steers $165 million to his alma maters

items.title: Traces of ancient seafloor cataclysms turn up in the Himalayas
items.description: Vast undersea eruptions may be undercounted source of extinctions through Earth’s history

items.title: Trump slump? Attendance plummets at some science meetings, but others hold steady
items.description: Amid travel bans, a government shutdown, and funding crunches, 2025 was a turbulent year for U.S. scientific societies

items.title: U.K. physics community braces for deep funding cuts
items.description: Research council to slash funding for particle physics, nuclear physics, and astronomy by 30%, prompting alarm across the research community
